item.content:encoded:
Swiftlet nest, also known as the “caviar of the east”, is one of the popular luxury food ingredients in Asia, especially in Indonesia, China, and Malaysia. In addition to being eaten in the form of Swiftlet nest jelly, Swiftlet nest can also be processed into various delicious and nutritious dishes, one of which is Swiftlet nest milk.

Swiftlet nest milk is a beverage made from a mixture of milk and Swiftlet nest. Swiftlet nest itself is known to be rich in nutrients and has various benefits for human health. Here are some benefits of Swiftlet nest milk:

1. Maintaining Skin Health

The collagen content in Swiftlet’s nest can help maintain skin health, increase skin elasticity and moisture, and reduce signs of aging.

2. Boosting Immune System

Swiftlet’s nest contains immunomodulatory compounds that can help boost the immune system and fight various diseases.

3. Improving Eye Health

The sialic acid content in Swiftlet’s nest can help maintain eye health and prevent vision disorders.

4. Maintaining Bone Health

The calcium content in Swiftlet’s nest can help maintain bone health and prevent osteoporosis.

5. Increasing Breast Milk Production

Swiftlet’s nest milk is known to increase breast milk production in nursing mothers.

6. Boosting Stamina

The protein, amino acid, and natural sugar content in Swiftlet’s nest can help boost stamina and energy in the body.

Based on the explanation above, it is known that Swiftlet’s nest milk has high nutritional content and is often considered a healthy food. However, like any other food or beverage, consuming Swiftlet’s nest milk excessively can cause side effects on the body. Some possible side effects of Swiftlet’s nest milk are:

1. Allergies

Swiftlet’s nest milk contains protein that can cause allergies in some people. Allergy symptoms that may occur include skin rashes, itching, swelling of the face or lips, and difficulty breathing. If you experience these symptoms after consuming Swiftlet’s nest milk, immediately stop consumption and consult a doctor.

2. Digestive Problems

Consuming Swiftlet’s nest milk in large quantities can cause digestive problems, such as diarrhea, bloating, and stomach pain. This can happen because Swiftlet’s nest milk contains high amounts of fat and protein, which take longer to digest by the body.

3. Weight Gain

The high calorie and fat content in Swiftlet’s nest milk can cause weight gain if consumed excessively. Consumption of Swiftlet’s nest milk should be balanced with physical activity.

4. Microbial Contamination

Unhygienic production or improper storage of Swiftlet’s nest milk can cause contamination by bacteria or other microorganisms. This can cause infections in the body, such as food poisoning.

To avoid the side effects of Swiftlet’s nest milk, it is recommended to consume it in balanced amounts and ensure that the Swiftlet’s nest milk consumed comes from a trusted producer. It is better to consult with a doctor or nutritionist before regularly consuming Swiftlet’s nest milk.

item.content:encoded:
Consuming Swiftlet saliva has become a trend in several Asian countries, as it is believed to have significant health benefits for the human body. However, many are wondering about the law regarding consuming Swiftlet saliva, especially from a religious and health perspective. What is the actual status of Swiftlet saliva, whether it is considered sacred or unclean?

From a religious perspective, consuming Swiftlet saliva is not considered haram in Islam or other religions, as Swiftlet are considered halal for consumption. This is because Swiftlet are considered halal birds to eat according to Islamic teachings, and their saliva is considered an inseparable part of their body.

According to the Shafi’i scholars, all types of fluids that ooze and drip from the inside of an animal follow the status of the animal. If the animal is considered sacred, then the fluid is considered sacred. However, if the animal is considered unclean, then the fluid is considered unclean.

As quoted from the Encyclopedia of Kuwaiti Scholars’ Fatwas (Al-Mausu’ah Al-Fiqhiyah Al-Kuwaitiyah):

ﻭﻳﻘﻮﻝ ﺍﻟﺸﺎﻓﻌﻴﺔ ﺇﻥ ﻣﺎ ﺍﻧﻔﺼﻞ ﻋﻦ ﺑﺎﻃﻦ ﺍﻟﺤﻴﻮﺍﻥ ﻭﻟﻴﺲ ﻟﻪ ﺍﺟﺘﻤﺎﻉ ﻭﺍﺳﺘﺤﺎﻟﺔ ﻓﻲ ﺍﻟﺒﺎﻃﻦ ﻭﺇﻧﻤﺎ ﻳﺮﺷﺢ ﺭﺷﺤﺎ ﻛﺎﻟﻠﻌﺎﺏ ﻭﺍﻟﺪﻣﻊ ﻭﺍﻟﻌﺮﻕ ﻭﺍﻟﻤﺨﺎﻁ ﻓﻠﻪ ﺣﻜﻢ ﺍﻟﺤﻴﻮﺍﻥ ﺍﻟﻤﺘﺮﺷﺢ ﻣﻨﻪ ﺇﻥ ﻛﺎﻥ ﻧﺠﺴﺎ ﻓﻨﺠﺲ ﻭﺇﻻ ﻓﻄﺎﻫﺮ

Meaning: The scholars of the Shafi’i school of thought said that all fluids that come out of the inside of an animal, and are not considered part of the animal itself but rather excretions like saliva, sweat, and mucus, are subject to the same ruling as the animal. If the animal is considered impure, then the fluids are also considered impure. Conversely, if the animal is considered pure, then the fluids are also considered pure. 

One of the evidence used to support this ruling is a hadith narrated by Imam Tirmidhi and Imam Ahmad, which states:

خطبنا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم بمنى وهو على راحلته ولعابها يسيل على كتف

Meaning: Prophet Muhammad once gave a sermon to us while in Mina. At that time, he was riding a camel. The camel’s saliva flowed onto my shoulder.

As the swiftlet is considered a sacred animal, the fluids that come out of its body, such as its saliva, sweat, and mucus, are considered sacred. This is different from dog saliva, as dogs are considered impure animals, so their saliva and all fluids that ooze from their body are considered impure.

Quoting another source, the Indonesian Council of Ulama’s Fatwa No. 02 of 2012 on Swiftlet Nests, which was issued on January 12, 2012, determined that:

  1. The nests of swiftlets, as referred to in the general provision, are considered pure and halal.
  2. If the swiftlet nests are mixed with or come into contact with impure substances (such as its feces), they must be purified according to Islamic law (tathhir syar’i) before consumption, as per the Fatwa of the Indonesian Ulama Council No. 2 of 2010.
  3. Breeding swiftlets is permissible according to Islamic law.

Although Swiftlet’s nest saliva is considered halal, if the way to obtain it involves unethical actions that harm the animals, it can be considered as actions that are not in line with Islamic values.

From a health perspective, consuming Swiftlet’s nest saliva is still debatable. Some studies have shown that Swiftlet’s nest saliva contains active compounds such as sialin and epidermal growth factor (EGF) that can help accelerate wound healing, boost the immune system, and maintain skin health. However, further research is still needed to prove more specific health benefits.

It should be noted that consuming Swiftlet’s nest saliva also carries risks. Swiftlets can carry dangerous bacteria and viruses that are harmful to human health, and if their saliva is not properly processed, it can cause diseases such as respiratory infections or digestive disorders. Additionally, if you have certain medical conditions or are taking medication, it is advisable to consult your doctor before consuming Swiftlet’s nest saliva. This is because consuming Swiftlet’s nest saliva or related products can affect your health condition and the interaction with the medication you are taking.

Therefore, if you want to consume Swiftlet’s nest saliva, make sure to buy it from a reliable source and ensure that the saliva has been properly processed to eliminate harmful bacteria and germs.

item.content:encoded:
Swiftlet’s nest is a popular food ingredient that has many health benefits. Before processing it, it is best to clean the Swiftlet’s nest first.

Cleaning the Swiftlet’s nest before processing it is very important. This is because the Swiftlet’s nest usually still contains dirt or residues from the environment where the swiftlet lives. Here are some tips for properly cleaning the Swiftlet’s nest:

1. Soak in Cold Water

The first step in cleaning the Swiftlet’s nest is to soak it in cold water for at least 30 minutes. This is to soften the nest and help lift the dirt that sticks to it.

2. Rinse with Clean Water

After soaking for 30 minutes, rinse the Swiftlet’s nest with clean water. Use a gentle water flow to rinse the Swiftlet’s nest until it is clean.

3. Wash with Warm Water

After rinsing with clean water, continue to wash the Swiftlet’s nest using warm water. Make sure the water temperature is not too hot, as water that is too hot can damage the quality of the Swiftlet’s nest.

If you want to soak the Swiftlet’s nest in hot water, the recommended soaking time is around 30 minutes to 1 hour. The soaking can be done using clean water that has been heated to a temperature of around 60-70 degrees Celsius.

Soaking the Swiftlet’s nest in hot water can help clean and remove dirt and dust that stick to the nest. However, it should be noted that not all types of Swiftlet’s nests can be soaked in hot water. High-quality Swiftlet’s nests should not be soaked in hot water as it can damage the structure and quality of the nest.

4. Avoid Using Soap or Detergent

Avoid using soap or detergent when washing the Swiftlet’s nest, as these materials can damage the quality of the Swiftlet’s nest and reduce its benefits.

5. Rinse Until Clean

After washing with warm water, rinse the Swiftlet’s nest until clean with cold water. Make sure there are no remnants of soap or detergent left on the nest.

6. Dry

After washing and rinsing the Swiftlet’s nest, dry it by placing it in a place exposed to direct sunlight or using a gentle dryer. Make sure the Swiftlet’s nest is completely dry before storing or processing.

Can Swiftlet’s Nest Expire?

Swiftlet’s nest is a natural product produced from the saliva of Swiftlet, and like other natural products, it can also expire. Expiration in Swiftlet’s nest occurs when the nest undergoes physical changes, such as unusual colors and smells, or when there is mold growing inside. Therefore, it is very important to check Swiftlet’s nest before consuming it.

However, because Swiftlet’s nest is a dry product and not easily contaminated by bacteria or mold, it has a relatively long shelf life, which is around 2 to 3 years if stored properly. To extend the shelf life of Swiftlet’s nest, it is recommended to store it in a dry, cool place, and away from direct sunlight.

It is important to remember that although Swiftlet’s nest is not easily contaminated by bacteria or mold, if the nest has expired, consuming it can still cause food poisoning or digestive problems. Therefore, always make sure to check the expiration date before consuming Swiftlet’s nest and dispose of it if it has passed the expiration date.

Swiftlet’s nest itself has a fairly high nutritional content and beneficial properties for human health. Here are some uses of Swiftlet’s nest that you need to know.

1. Boosting the Immune System

Swiftlet’s nest contains protein, minerals, and collagen that can help boost the immune system. Some studies also show that Swiftlet’s nest contains active compounds such as sialic acid and epidermal growth factor (EGF) that can help improve immunity.

2. Rejuvenating the Skin

Swiftlet’s nest is also known to have benefits for rejuvenating the skin. Its collagen and protein content can help stimulate collagen production in the skin, making the skin appear firmer and more elastic. In addition, Swiftlet’s nest can also help reduce wrinkles and fine lines on the face.

3. Improving Bone Health

Swiftlet’s nest contains minerals such as calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus that are beneficial for bone health. Calcium and phosphorus, in particular, are important for the formation and maintenance of healthy bones. Additionally, Swiftlet’s nest also contains protein that is needed to strengthen and repair bone tissue.

4. Maintaining Heart Health

Swiftlet’s nest can also help maintain heart health. Some studies show that Swiftlet’s nest can help lower cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood, which can help reduce the risk of heart disease.

5. Supporting Digestive Health

Swiftlet’s nest contains fiber that can help improve digestive function and prevent constipation. Additionally, Swiftlet’s nest also contains complex carbohydrates that can help maintain blood sugar balance.

6. Boosting Energy

Swiftlet’s nest can also help increase energy and reduce fatigue. Its nutritional content can help increase body metabolism and improve physical condition.

Can Swiftlet's Nest Be Consumed Every Day?

The explanation above is about the benefits of swiftlet’s nest that you need to know. However, it is important to remember that consumption of swiftlet’s nest should be done wisely and in moderation. If it does provide many benefits, can swiftlet’s nest be consumed every day?

Like any other food, consumption of swiftlet’s nest should be done wisely. Consuming swiftlet’s nest every day is not recommended because there are several risks associated with excessive consumption, such as:

1. Contamination

Commercially produced swiftlet’s nest may contain unsafe contaminants such as dirt or chemicals if not processed properly.

2. Allergy

Some people may have an allergy to swiftlet’s nest that can cause symptoms such as skin rash, itching, or difficulty breathing.

3. Cost

Swiftlet’s nest is one of the most expensive foods in the world, which can cause excessive consumption to be a significant financial burden.

In this case, it is advisable to consume swiftlet’s nest wisely and in moderation, such as consuming it once or twice a week. Remember to buy swiftlet’s nest from a trusted producer and properly processed. Don’t consume it too often, so that the health risks associated with excessive consumption of swiftlet’s nest can be avoided.

item.content:encoded:
Swiftlets are highly valued for their saliva, which is used to create swiftlet nests, a luxury food item used in health supplements and cosmetics. However, many people are not aware of how long swiftlets produce their saliva.

Adult swiftlets typically begin producing saliva when they reach the age of around 5-6 months. This process occurs naturally, especially during the rainy season. During the rainy season, swiftlets will enter the breeding season and begin building their nests in safe and protected locations.

When swiftlets start building their nests, they will produce saliva that is secreted from glands located under their tongue. This saliva contains many proteins, carbohydrates, and other essential nutrients that swiftlets need to survive.

Swiftlets can continue producing saliva for several years. However, saliva production is influenced by many factors, such as season, climate, and the food they consume. In addition, swiftlets will also stop producing saliva when they feel disturbed or stressed, for example, due to human disturbance or predators around their nests.

Swiftlet nests are one of the commodities that have high economic value. These nests are very popular in Indonesia, as they have high nutritional content and incredible health benefits. Therefore, many swiftlet nest farmers want to know how often they can harvest swiftlet nests.

It should be noted that the process of harvesting swiftlet nests cannot be done every month. The harvesting process of swiftlet nests must be done when the nest is mature or sufficiently hard, but not too hard. Nests that are too hard are difficult to harvest, while nests that are still too soft can affect the quality of the swiftlet nests produced.

Usually, the time interval between swiftlet nest harvests is around 2-3 months. However, this also depends on several factors such as environmental conditions, the feeding pattern of the swiftlets, and water availability. Healthy and well-maintained swiftlets will produce more and higher-quality swiftlet nests.

In addition, the process of harvesting swiftlet nests must also be done carefully and with the right technique. If the harvesting process is not done properly, it can cause damage to the nest and the swiftlets inside. Therefore, breeders must have sufficient skills and experience in the process of harvesting swiftlet nests. Here are the correct ways to harvest swiftlet nests:

1. Equipment Preparation

The equipment required for harvesting bird’s nest includes a ladder, rope, flashlight, and a knife. Make sure all equipment is prepared and in good condition before starting the harvesting process.

2. Check Nest Condition

Before harvesting bird’s nest, make sure to check the condition of the nest and ensure that it is mature enough. Bird’s nest that is too soft or too hard cannot be harvested and can damage the nest and the birds inside.

3. Wait Until Night

Bird’s nest is active at night when they come out of the nest to find food. Therefore, the process of harvesting bird’s nest should be done at night when the birds are out looking for food.

4. Climb to the Ceiling

Usually, bird’s nests are located on the ceiling or in places that are difficult to reach. Climb to the ceiling with a ladder and ensure safety by always wearing safety equipment such as a helmet and safety rope.

5. Use a Flashlight

Bird’s nests are usually in dark places, so use a flashlight to help see the bird’s nest that is ready to be harvested.

6. Cut Bird's Nest with a Knife

After finding the bird’s nest that is ready to be harvested, cut the nest with a sharp knife. Make sure to cut the nest carefully to avoid damaging the bird’s nest.

7. Store the Nest Properly

After harvesting the bird’s nest, make sure to store it properly. Store the bird’s nest in a dry place and away from direct sunlight.

item.content:encoded:
Swiflets and swifts are two bird species that are often associated with bird’s nests. These birds have significant differences in appearance, characteristics, and habitats. However, interestingly, both types of birds can coexist in the same building.

Swiflets

Swiflets (Aerodramus spp.) are birds that produce bird’s nest and live in caves and high buildings. There are several types of swiflets found in the world, including White-nest Swiftlet (Aerodramus fuciphagus), Black-nest Swiftlet (Aerodramus maximus), and Indian Swiftlet (Aerodramus unicolor).

Swiflets are endemic to Southeast Asia and the Pacific regions. They live in large colonies that can reach hundreds of thousands of birds, and the bird’s nest produced by the original swiflet has a high price due to its good quality and international halal recognition.

Swifts

Swifts (Apodidae spp.) are also birds that produce bird’s nests but differ from swiflets. In Indonesia, there are two types of swifts, namely Edible-nest Swiftlet (Collocolia esculenta) and Mossy-nest Swiftlet (Collocolia vanikorensis).

At first glance, there is no striking difference between the types of swiftlets; the difference lies only in their feet. Swifts live in a different environment than swiflets, more commonly found in open environments such as forests or lowlands, and they build nests in cracks or specific parts inside caves.

Differences between Swiflets and Swifts

In general, the differences between swiflets and swifts can be seen from several aspects, as follows:

1. Feather Color

Swiflets have dark brown or black feathers, while swifts have light brown or grayish feathers.

2. Nest Color

Swiflets’ nests are ivory white, while swifts’ nests have greenish-brown color.

3. Habitat

Swiflets live in caves and high buildings, while swifts are more commonly found in open environments such as forests or lowlands.

4. Flying Movement

Swiflets fly with very fast and agile movements, while swifts fly with slower and more regular movements.

5. Feeding Habits

Swiflets usually fly in the air to catch flying insects, while swifts rely more on short flights to find food sources such as flowers or small insects.

6. Feeding Method

In terms of feeding method, swiflets and swifts also have differences. Swiflets take flying insects using their small and pointed beaks, while swifts use their long and forked tongues to suck flower nectar or lick small insects that they consume.

7. Body Size

Swiflets have larger body sizes than swifts. Swiflets have a body length of around 10-12 cm with long and narrow wings, while swifts are only about 9-10 cm with wings that are also narrow but wider than swiflets.

8. Nest Building Process

Swiflets make nests using only their saliva without any other material, while swifts also use a mixture of leaves, moss, and grass around them.

9. Types of Food

Swiftlets only eat large amounts of flying insects as their food. They fly in the air at night to catch flying insects such as mosquitoes, flies, and butterflies.

Sunbirds also eat flying insects, but their main food is flower nectar. In addition, sunbirds can eat small insects like small lice and fruit flies, as well as fine dust particles found in the air. They can also eat small fruits and grains.

10. Fluid Requirements

Swiftlets need water to drink and maintain their body balance. However, because they often fly and do not have easy access to water, swiftlets usually get water from the water condensation that forms on cave walls or tall buildings where they nest. However, when the weather is very dry and there is no water available from condensation, swiftlets can fly far to find water sources such as rivers or lakes to meet their water needs.

Like swiftlets, sunbirds also drink water to maintain fluid balance in their bodies. However, sunbirds do not always need a lot of water because they usually obtain most of their fluid from the flower nectar they suck. Sunbirds can drink water from natural water sources such as rivers, lakes, or other water sources if there are no other water sources available.

item.content:encoded:
Swiftlet birds live in the wild and choose hard-to-reach locations such as coastal cliffs, caves, and tall buildings to build their nests. The bird’s nests are made of a mixture of swiftlet saliva and other materials such as feathers.

However, obtaining swiftlet nests from the wild is difficult and dangerous since swiftlets usually build their nests in hard-to-reach locations like coastal cliffs and tall buildings. Therefore, farmers have developed ways to cultivate swiftlets and collect their saliva from nests made in specific locations such as caves and high-rise buildings.

Why Are Swiftlet Nests Expensive?

The process of making swiftlet nests and collecting their saliva is difficult and time-consuming. Swiftlet saliva is carefully collected and processed with modern technology to maintain its quality and cleanliness. Because this process takes a long time and requires a lot of resources, the price of swiftlet saliva becomes very expensive.

However, consumers are still willing to pay a high price to get the health and beauty benefits associated with swiftlet saliva. Some studies have shown that swiftlet saliva contains collagen and protein that are good for skin health and accelerate cell regeneration. In addition, swiftlet saliva is also known to increase growth hormone production and boost the immune system. This is another factor that makes the price of swiftlet saliva expensive.

How Much Does 1 Kilogram of Swiftlet Saliva Cost?

We know that the process of taking swiftlet saliva is costly and time-consuming. So, how expensive is the actual price of 1 kilogram of swiftlet saliva?

The price of 1 kilogram of swiftlet saliva varies depending on the quality, quantity, and purchase location. In traditional markets, the price of 1 kilogram of swiftlet saliva ranges from 5 to 10 million rupiah in Indonesia. However, the price can be much higher if the swiftlet saliva comes from wild nests that are hard to reach, such as coastal cliffs or high-rise buildings. The price of pure swiftlet saliva from wild nests can reach hundreds of millions of rupiah per kilogram.

Swiftlet farming has been developed in several Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. The swiftlet farming industry and mass production of swiftlet saliva have helped to lower the price of swiftlet saliva and make it more affordable. However, the process of producing swiftlet saliva still requires a significant amount of time and resources, so the price of swiftlet saliva remains high.

Although the price of swiftlet saliva is very expensive, beverages and foods containing swiftlet saliva are still popular in Asia. Some well-known beverage brands in Asia even offer products containing pure swiftlet saliva at a very high price. This indicates that the demand for swiftlet saliva is still high despite its high price.

item.content:encoded:
According to The New York Times, swiftlet nests are not made in the usual way that birds make nests from leaves and branches. Swiftlet nests are made from the bird’s own saliva that dries and forms a fiber cluster. This nest is highly sought after and is one of the most expensive dishes in the world. Swiftlet nests are a luxurious food product that is highly demanded in Asia, especially in China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.

Swiftlet nests are one of the most valuable products on the market. The price of swiftlet nests varies depending on the quality and size of the nest. Prices can reach tens of millions of rupiahs per kilogram. The price of a bowl-shaped swiftlet nest can be sold for 13 million rupiahs per kilogram, while the price of a corner-shaped swiftlet nest can reach 9 million rupiahs per kilogram. A broken swiftlet nest can reach 8 million rupiahs per kilogram. Meanwhile, the price of one ounce of swiftlet nest ranges from 800 thousand rupiahs to 1.3 million rupiahs. These prices vary in each region, but the large profits gained from swiftlet nests attract many people.

Indonesia is one of the largest swiftlet nest producers in the world, and it is one of Indonesia’s main export commodities. Indonesian swiftlet nests are known for their good quality and international recognition for halal certification.

According to the Central Statistics Agency (BPS), the value of Indonesia’s bird’s nest export reached US$517.03 million with a volume of 1,505.5 tons in 2021. Looking at the value, bird’s nest export decreased by 4.27% compared to the previous year, which was US$540.37 million.

Meanwhile, the volume of Indonesia’s bird’s nest export has increased by 14.7% annually. In 2020, the volume of bird’s nest export was recorded at 1,312.5 tons. Looking at the trend, Indonesia’s bird’s nest export value has fluctuated over the past ten years. Bird’s nest export reached its highest level of US$540.37 million in 2020.

The price of natural swiftlet nests can reach thousands of dollars per kilogram, depending on the size and quality of the nest. The price of this type of nest is highly influenced by market demand and the supply of swiftlet nests. Rare and difficult to obtain natural swiftlet nests can reach very high prices in the market.

In addition to natural swiftlet nests, there are also swiftlet nests produced from colonies of swiftlets that are raised in a controlled environment. These nests are known as “cultured swiftlet nests” and are more affordable than natural swiftlet nests. Cultured swiftlet nests can be obtained at prices ranging from hundreds to thousands of dollars per kilogram, depending on the quality and size of the nest.

Despite the high price of swiftlet nests, demand for this product continues to increase due to its popularity as a luxurious food ingredient and traditional medicine. So, who are the actual consumers of swiftlet nests?

1. Entrepreneurs

Swiftlet nests are a very valuable product, so they are usually bought by entrepreneurs who want to profit from this product. Entrepreneurs will buy swiftlet nests in large quantities and sell them at higher prices to make a profit.

2. Culinary Enthusiasts

Swiftlet nests are also used as a highly valued food ingredient in luxury cuisine. Some dishes that use swiftlet nests include swiftlet nest soup or fried swiftlet nests. Swiftlet nests are usually sold at very high prices in luxury restaurants and are usually bought by people who want to taste this luxurious dish.

3. Traditional Medicine Enthusiasts

Swiftlet nests are also used in traditional medicine. Some people believe that swiftlet nests have healing properties and can improve overall health. Swiftlet nests are usually purchased by individuals who want to try this traditional treatment or believe in the health benefits of swiftlet nests.

4. Government and Educational Institutions

Governments and educational institutions also buy swiftlet nests for research and development purposes. Some studies are conducted to explore the health benefits of swiftlet nests or to develop more efficient swiftlet nest production technology.

However, it should be noted that the very high price of swiftlet nests is sometimes caused by fraudulent practices or the counterfeiting of swiftlet nests. Some dishonest swiftlet nest sellers may mix other ingredients into the swiftlet nests or alter the shape and appearance of the swiftlet nests to make them look more attractive, but the quality and nutritional value of the swiftlet nests may decrease.
